title: Enslaved Persons in the Making of Societies and Cultures in Western Eurasia and Africa, 1000 BCE - 300 CE
descriptions:
This grant proposal seeks funding for the project "Enslaved Persons in the Making of Societies and Cultures in Western Eurasia and Africa, 1000 BCE - 300 CE," also known as SLaVEgents. The project focuses on the agency of enslaved individuals during the time period from -1000 to 300, covering regions in Western Eurasia and North Africa. The research will encompass languages such as Assyrian, Babylonian, Hebrew, Aramaic, Phoenician, Egyptian, Greek, and Latin.

The research team consists of 1 Principal Investigator, 8 senior researchers, 7 post-doctoral researchers, and 3 PhD candidates, who will produce a variety of research outputs including a digital prosopography, 1 monograph, 2 collective volumes, 15 articles, 3 PhD dissertations, and organize 3 workshops and an international conference. The project will also include the development of a website to disseminate findings.

The project aims to analyze the impact of enslaved persons on ancient societies and cultures, examining their various identities, communities, and networks, and the ways in which they influenced historical developments. This grant proposal seeks to support a comprehensive and interdisciplinary investigation into the role of enslaved individuals in shaping the history of Western Eurasia and Africa during the specified time frame.

The "Enslaved Persons in the Making of Societies and Cultures in Western Eurasia and Africa, 1000 BCE - 300 CE" project, known as SLaVEgents, focuses on exploring the agency of enslaved individuals during a crucial time period in history. The project covers Western Eurasia and North Africa, delving into languages such as Assyrian, Babylonian, Hebrew, and Greek. Led by a diverse research team, including a Principal Investigator, senior researchers, post-doctoral researchers, and PhD candidates, the project aims to produce a range of research outputs, including a digital prosopography, a monograph, collective volumes, articles, PhD dissertations, workshops, an international conference, and a dedicated website.

By examining the multiple identities, communities, and networks of enslaved persons, the project seeks to shed light on the significant historical impact these individuals had on ancient societies and cultures. Through a comprehensive analysis of historical sources and data, the research team will contribute valuable insights to the field of ancient history and social studies. The SLaVEgents project represents a critical opportunity to advance our understanding of the complexities of slavery and its role in shaping the past, offering a unique perspective on the dynamics of power, resistance, and cultural exchange during this pivotal period in history.
